title: Cyprus - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: On 5 February 2021, Greek Cypriots, who were displaced from Northern Cyprus during the 1974 Turkish invasion and were temporarily given Turkish Cypriot (who in turn were displaced to the north) properties in Pafos to reside in, protested against the mayor's and the local authority's management of these properties, which they consider to be arbitrary, and the protesters claim it lacks respect to the tenants. [size=no report]
Property destruction: On 5 February 2021, unidentified assailants torched the car of a lawyer in Limassol, who is also the president of a 2nd division football team and a candidate lawmaker.

On 3 February 2021, about 200 refugees in the Pournara reception center in Kokkinotrimithia marched out of the center to protest over their living conditions and their protracted detention in the facility due to the coronavirus pandemic. Riot police arrived as a precaution. The refugees shouted slogans and returned to the center when their protest was over. [size=no report]

On 2 February 2021, Kurdish people of Limassol rallied at the Kurdistan Cultural Centre 'Theofilos' and started a hunger-strike to express their solidarity with the 700 Kurds on hunger-strike in Turkish prisons, with Kurdish hunger-strikers in Lavrio, Greece, and with Kurdish protesters on hunger-strike outside the United Nations offices in Geneva. The protesters demanded information on Kurdish leader Abdullah Ocalan, who is jailed in Turkey, and decried the imprisonment of tens of thousands of political prisoners in Turkey. [size=no report]

On 1 February 2021, refugees in the Pournara reception center in Kokkinotrimithia protested within the center over their living conditions and their protracted detention in the facility due to the coronavirus pandemic. The protesters held banners in English and Arabic demanding permission to leave the premises. [size=no report]

On 25 January 2021, tens of Turkish Cypriot workers living in Northern Cyprus and working in the Republic of Cyprus continued their protest against the coronavirus quarantine restrictions preventing them from commuting to work. They rallied at the Ayios Dhometios border (Kermiya/Metehan) holding placards reading 'Be fair' and 'Respect for the workers' asking Turkish Cypriot authorities to apply the same rules to them as to their counterparts working in the British Bases or the buffer zone. [size=tens]

Security measures: On 25 January 2021, the Turkish Cypriot administration [coded to Nicosia] implemented longer curfew hours in Northern Cyprus, and on 26 January ordered a full-day lockdown in Nicosia and Kyrenia. The general lockdown was applied to the rest of the country on 29 January to be effective until 3 February and longer in areas with a heavier epidemiological burden.
KTOEOS: Cyprus Turkish Secondary School Teachers Union; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Teachers (Cyprus)

On 25 January 2021, members of KTOEOS protested outside the Guzelyurt Vocational School in Morphou over the decisions taken by the Ministry of National Education and Culture and the Ministry of Health Contagious Diseases Supreme Committee, demanding increased coronavirus safety measures in schools. [size=no report]

On 25 January 2021, Turkish Cypriot workers living in Northern Cyprus and working in the Republic of Cyprus continued their protest against the coronavirus quarantine restrictions preventing them from commuting to work. They rallied at the Agios Nikolaos checkpoint in Strovilia asking Turkish Cypriot authorities to apply the same rules to them as to their counterparts working in the British Bases or the buffer zone. [size=no report]

On 21 January 2021, Turkish Cypriot workers living in Northern Cyprus and working in the Republic of Cyprus continued their protest against the coronavirus restrictions preventing them from commuting to work, and over the conditions of their quarantine. They rallied at the border in Strovilia (Akyar Border Gate) demanding solutions from the government. [size=no report]

On 21 January 2021, trade unionists protested outside parliament in Northern Nicosia to demand an increase in the budget allocated for the municipalities in Northern Cyprus, claiming that, during the coronavirus pandemic, responsibilities have increased, but contributions they receive by the state have decreased. [size=no report]

On 18 January 2021, mothers, who are residents of Agioi Konstantinos kai Eleni in Dali, demonstrated outside a health center in Latsia, in Greater Nicosia, demanding the relocation of the asphalt plants causing air pollution in residential areas. The protesters, who were holding a banner reading 'We breathe whatever they burn', timed their protest as President Anastasiadis was receiving the second dose of the Covid-19 vaccine and managed to meet him. [size=no report]
KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labour Group (Cyprus); Health Workers (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

On 18 January 2021, Turkish Cypriot civil servants represented by KTAMS and Kamu-Sen rallied outside Famagusta hospital during a protest-strike over the increased workload of health workers due to understaffing. Public health workers also protested that they have not been paid for 6 months. [size=no report]

On 14 January 2021, members of the Turkish Cypriot Electricity Authority Employees' Union (EL-SEN) rallied outside the Turkish Cypriot Electricity Authority (KIB-TEK) in Northern Nicosia. Their president read a statement demanding that the Deputy Prime Minister and Finance and Energy Minister reveals the corruption allegations in KIB-TEK, and called for urgent and short-term investments in the institution. [size=no report]

On 13 January 2021, the Federation of Free Trade Unions (Hur-Is) protested in front of the Ministry of Labor and Social Security in Northern Nicosia over the fact that the minimum wage has not been determined yet. [size=no report]

KTOEOS: Cyprus Turkish Secondary School Teachers Union; KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Health Workers (Cyprus); Teachers (Cyprus); Labour Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

On 12 January 2021, members of the authorized public sector unions KTOEOS, KTOS, KTAMS, Medicine-Is and the Nurses and Midwives Union protested outside the Ministry of Finance in Northern Nicosia over the new government's failure to initiate protocol negotiations, and demanded the adjustment of the minimum wage according to current conditions. [size=no report]

On 11 January 2021, about 600 refugees from various African states and from Syria clashed at the Pournara refugee reception center in Kokkinotrimithia. The cause of the unrest is likely overcrowding due to the coronavirus lockdown in addition to an increase in their numbers. The rioters hurled rocks and attacked each other with brass knuckles. Windowpanes were shattered, beds and other equipment smashed and a section of the camp's fencing sustained extensive damage. Riot police arrested 4 Syrians and 4 Africans. 35 refugees were injured, of which 24 were transferred to hospital for first aid. [size=about 600]

On 11 January 2021, about 150 Turkish Cypriot workers living in Northern Cyprus and working in the Republic of Cyprus continued their demonstrations against the coronavirus restrictions preventing them from commuting to work. They marched to parliament in Northern Nicosia, where there were scuffles (verbal confrontations and pushing) with police that had formed a cordon. The demonstrators, who became organized as an association with the name 'Turkish Cypriot Workers in the South', demanded the same treatment as the employees in the British Bases, and as the residents of the village of Pyla, which is located inside the United Nations buffer zone. The Prime Minister received 3 of their representatives. [size=about 150]

On 9 January 2021, relatives of prisoners in Northern Nicosia Central Prison, who had started a hunger strike the day before, protested in solidarity in front of the prison. They demanded better conditions in prisons during the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

On 9 January 2021, protesters against the renewed coronavirus lockdown, who were organized through social media, gathered in Nicosia driving 50 cars. They then marched to the Ledras crossing point shouting slogans. They were observed by police forces. The following day 1 of the organizers was identified and charged. [size=at least 50]

On 9 January 2021, mothers, who are residents of Agioi Konstantinos kai Eleni in Dali, demonstrated spontaneously against pollution caused by the nearby asphalt plant. They drove to the factory, which continued to operate throughout the day, honking their horns and creating a lot of noise. [size=no report]

On 8 January 2021, members of the Tourism Workers Platform rallied in Northern Nicosia laying a wreath outside the office of the Prime Minister to protest for support as their sector was hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

On 4 January 2021, 200-300 protesters - according to police estimates - participated in a motorcade of 200 vehicles around Nicosia against the coronavirus lockdown measures banning rallies and gatherings. The protesters drove to the Presidential palace, where strong police forces prevented them from reaching the gates. There were 2 arrests and 9 people were fined. [size=200-300]
On 29 December 2020, members of labor groups participated in a protest-strike outside the prime minister's office in Northern Nicosia over unpaid salaries. [size=no report]
AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Labour Group (Cyprus); Government of Greece (2019-)

On 24 December 2020, members and lawmakers of AKEL joined owners of small and medium businesses in a protest rally in Limassol over the problems their sector is facing due to the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]
KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labour Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

On 22 December 2020, members of KTAMS protested outside of parliament in Northern Nicosia against the government rejecting the resignation of a UBP deputy staying in Istanbul, but receiving a salary from Northern Cyprus. [size=no report]

On 21 December 2020, parents of students already flying from Great Britain to Cyprus protested at Larnaca airport against their children's 7-day coronavirus quarantine in hotels arranged by the state, and over the late warning for this additional measure. [size=no report]

On 21 December 2020, parents of students already flying from Great Britain to Cyprus protested at Pafos airport against their children's 7-day coronavirus quarantine in hotels arranged by the state, and over the late warning for this additional measure. [size=no report]
On 19 December 2020, the Iskele Environment and Coasts Protection Initiative protested at 'Long Beach' [coded to Trikomo] against plans for hotel construction. [size=no report]

On 17 December 2020, members of the Public Workers Union participated in a protest-strike at the Agricultural Products Corporation in Nicosia over unpaid insurance and reserve fund premiums of the employees. The protesters unfurled banners. [size=no report]
On 16 December 2020, trade unionists protested outside the Ministry of Labor in Northern Nicosia for an increase of the minimum wage. The protesters also held a press conference. [size=no report]

On 16 December 2020, on the second day of their protest, Turkish Cypriots living in Northern Cyprus and working in the Republic of Cyprus drove to the Pergamos (Kermiya) crossing point to protest against new coronavirus rules by the Turkish Cypriot administration closing the border. The demonstrators then briefly disrupted traffic in Nicosia protesting outside the Prime Minister's office, where he received their representatives. [size=no report]

Security measures: On 15 December 2020, the Turkish Cypriot administration [coded to Nicosia] introduced new coronavirus restrictions closing border crossing points to the Republic of Cyprus, and introducing quarantine measures for Turkish Cypriots commuting to the south that continued into the new year, and implementing a 5-day night-time curfew on New Year's Eve and again on 17 January.

On 15 December 2020, around 100 Turkish Cypriots living in Northern Cyprus and working in the Republic of Cyprus protested at the Ayios Dhometios (Metehan) crossing point against new coronavirus rules by the Turkish Cypriot administration closing the border. The demonstrators walked to northern Nicosia in protest and attempted to enter the Prime Minister's office. One demonstrator was detained briefly and was let go after the protesters agreed to leave the premises. They continued their protest at a nearby empty land. [size=around 100]

On 13 December 2020, unidentified perpetrators used a makeshift explosive device to blast the entrance of a telecommunications provider in Limassol. Police suspect 5G opponents as there were slogans written on the building against 5G networks. 2 more makeshift explosive devices went off at a bank branch and 5 hooded assailants hurled petrol bombs, attempting to burn down a Christmas tree. Police are investigatign a possible link between the 3 consecutive attacks. On 19 January 2021, police arrested a contract soldier in the National Guard.

Security measures: On 10 December 2020, the Government of Cyprus [coded to Nicosia] re-introduced stricter measures, including a night-time curfew and a ban on public and private gatherings. In addition, the government introduced daytime movement restrictions.

On 10 December 2020, on the day the government of Cyprus announced stricter coronavirus measures due to a resurgence in the pandemic, demonstrators marched against the new restrictions, but also against political corruption. They clashed with police, who prevented them from entering a TV station in Nicosia. The demonstrators then blocked the road disrupting traffic and shouted slogans against police and journalists. They hurled rocks and smoke canisters at the police, who used water cannons to disperse the crowd. Cars were damaged. There were 3 arrests. 2 police officers and 1 demonstrator were injured. On 14 December, there were 2 more arrests. [size=no report]
Labour Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Police Forces of Northern Cyprus (2020-)

On 8 December 2020, members of the Customs Employees Union (GUC-SEN) rallied outside the Public Service Commission in Northern Nicosia, where they left a black wreath and held a press release to protest over understaffing. [size=no report]
CTP: Republican Turkish Party; TDP: Communal Democracy Party; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

On 5 December 2020, Turkish Cypriot youth civil society organizations organized a large 'March for Peace' in Northern Nicosia. The protesters, who called themselves 'peace walkers', rejected all kinds of ethnic and religious discrimination and marched to the Ledras/Lokmaci crossing point. Members of TDP, CTP Youth, and of the Left Movement and the Revolutionary Communist Union also participated in the march. [size=large]
KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labour Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

On 4 December 2020, private sector employees and members of KTAMS protested outside the Ministry of Labor and Social Security in Northern Nicosia requesting an urgent meeting of the Minimum Wage Determination Commission for the re-determination of the minimum wage. [size=no report]

On 3 December 2020, despite a ban on gatherings, protesters against corruption (following the recent passports scandal) and against the government's coronavirus measures rallied outside a conference center in Nicosia that is temporarily hosting parliamentary sessions. The protesters shouted slogans against lawmakers. 10 people were fined for breaking the coronavirus ban. The protesters then participated in a motorcade in Nicosia. [size=no report]
Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

On 2 December 2020, Turkish Cypriots organized by the Association 'Peace' protested for a federal solution for Cyprus during the arrival of the UN special envoy in Northern Nicosia. On the other side of the Green Line, Greek Cypriots from Famagusta also protested for the same issue outside the presidential palace in Nicosia and unfurled a banner against the two-state solution. [size=no report]

On 2 December 2020, 45 kidney patients who receive dialysis at the Famagusta general hospital in the Republic of Cyprus staged a three-hour demonstration protesting against the lack of doctors in the unit in the afternoons, during weekends and holidays. This is an issue that existed before Covid-19. [size=45]

On 1 December 2020, teachers rallied, holding a banner in front of the Ministry of Education and Culture in Northern Nicosia, protesting that college exams are not utilizing a modern assessment system, arguing that they create inequality among students and should be abolished. [size=no report]
KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labour Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

On 26 November 2020, members of KTAMS rallied outside the Presidential office in Northern Nicosia to protest over President Tatar recruiting 16 temporary workers at the Prime Minister's office using the Prime Minister's signature when he was already President. The protesters argued that the duties and responsibilities of the Prime Minister were suspended, therefore he was not authorized to appoint these workers to public institutions. [size=no report]
KTOEOS: Cyprus Turkish Secondary School Teachers Union; Teachers (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

On 23 November 2020, ahead of Teachers' Day on 24 November, Cyprus Turkish Secondary Education Teachers Union (KTOEOS) and Cyprus Turkish Teachers' Union (KTOS) held a demonstration outside parliament in Northern Nicosia protesting for 'Non Dogmatic, Public Scientific Democratic and Contemporary Education'. [size=no report]

On 21 November 2020, about 30-40 masked protesters entered classes in Dasoupoli High School in Nicosia scattering fliers. The content of the slogans on the fliers was not reported. The protesters left without causing any damages. [size=30-40]
Labour Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Police Forces of Northern Cyprus (2020-)
On 20 November 2020, customs officers with the support of their unions participated in a protest-strike outside the Customs Office in Northern Nicosia due to lack of personnel. [size=no report]
Government of Cyprus (2013-); Cyprus Green Party

On 19 November 2020, residents of Agioi Konstantinos kai Eleni in Dali demonstrated spontaneously when the smell became unbearable against pollution caused by the nearby asphalt plant by blocking its gate with their cars hindering the factory's operation. The mayor of Dali and a Green Party lawmaker also participated in the motorcade. [size=no report]

On 17 November 2020, 6 of the 16 asylum seekers at the migrant reception center in Kofinou, who were found positive to the coronavirus, refused to be transferred to another facility and started vandalizing the reception center. Local police officers called for reinforcements from Larnaca. [size=6]

On 15 November 2020, on the day Turkish President Erdogan organized a picnic in Varosha/Maras at Famagusta in Northern Cyprus, Greek Cypriot students marched to the Lidras checkpoint in Nicosia protesting against the opening of Varosha beachfront against UN resolutions, the arrival of Erdogan on the island, and the provocative picnic in Varosha. Strong police forces were observing the march. [size=no report]
Government of Cyprus (2013-); Students (Cyprus); Cyprus Green Party; Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

On 15 November 2020, on the day Turkish President Erdogan organized a picnic in Varosha/Maras at Famagusta in Northern Cyprus, the municipal council of Famagusta walked to the checkpoint in Deryneia to protest against Erdogan's plans to impose a two-state solution to the Cyprus problem. In a statement, the mayor admitted that Greek Cypriots also made mistakes, but called for unity at the last moment, and asked of the UNSG to stop being neutral as Turkey is violating UN resolutions. Students and representatives of the Green Party also participated in the walk and planted olive trees as a symbol of peace. [size=no report]
CTP: Republican Turkish Party; TDP: Communal Democracy Party; Independence Road; UCN: Unite Cyprus Now; Labour Group (Cyprus); Lawyers (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

On 15 November 2020, on the day Turkish President Erdogan organized a picnic in Varosha/Maras at Famagusta in Northern Cyprus, Turkish Cypriots protested in three separate marches in Northern Nicosia holding banners with the slogan 'No picnic over pain'. CTP Youth organized the action 'Struggle for Peace and Democracy' and marched holding a banner reading 'Let us remind you, this country is ours'. CTP leadership also participated. TDP Youth organized the action 'Unity, Struggle and Solidarity'. The 3rd march was organized by Independence Road, Left Movement and Baraka Cultural Center with the participation of Unite Cyprus Now, labor groups and members of the Union of Turkish Bar Associations. Protesters shouted 'Block Erdogan, not people' when police barricades prevented them from reaching the Turkish embassy. They also chanted 'Erdogan take your hands off our collar'. [size=no report]

On 14 November 2020, following stricter local coronavirus lockdown measures in Limassol and Pafos, hundreds demonstrated in Limassol against the government's restrictions. 130 police officers were deployed. Some demonstrators turned violent setting fire to garbage bins, using firecrackers and hurling rocks at shop windows. Police responded by using a water canon and tear gas. More than 20 rioters were arrested. 3 police officers were injured lightly. Police discovered 6 petrol bombs hidden nearby. [size=hundreds]

On 11 November 2020, members of the Cyprus Turkish Teachers' Union (KTOS) protested over the continuing lack of teachers in primary schools at the school yard of Mandres (Hamitkoy) primary school, where the KTOS president read a press release. [size=no report]

Weapons seizure: On 11 November 2020, Cyprus police following information tips located 5 incendiary devices in the Larnaca region likely connected to the 14 November riots in Limassol against the government's coronavirus measures and lockdown.
CTP: Republican Turkish Party; TDP: Communal Democracy Party; Government of Northern Cyprus (2020-); Labour Group (Cyprus); DP: Democratic Party; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
Greek Reporter; LGC News; Yeniduzen; Philenews; SigmaLive; Detay

On 10 November 2020, more than 3,000 protesters organized by the 'Democracy and Will' platform marched to Inonu Square in Northern Nicosia against Turkish political intervention in the democracy of Northern Cyprus following what transpired during and after the 2020 presidential elections and ahead of a visit to Varosha/Maras by Turkish President Erdogan. Former Turkish Cypriot President Mustafa Akinci, leaders and members of political parties CTP, TDP, DP, the mayor of the Nicosia Turkish Municipality (NTM), and members of the trade union platform participated in the protest. The organizers held a speech. The protesters were holding placards reading 'Cyprus is secular, it will remain secular' and 'Cypriots have the Last Word in Cyprus', 'Self-Determination, Not Intervention' among many slogans for freedom, peace and unity, and they raised their phone lights in the air singing Bella Ciao. [size=more than 3,000]
AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People

On 7 November 2020, members of AKEL rallied outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia protesting over the passports scandal brought to light by the Al Jazeera network, and they accused the government of attempting to cover it up. [size=no report]

On 6 November 2020, members of the Movement 'Active Citizens ' and of the Platform 'End Corruption' rallied outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia demanding the resignation of those responsible for the passports scandal brought to light by the Al Jazeera network, and they accused the government of attempting to cover it up. [size=no report]

On 6 November 2020, senior high school students in Nicosia protested at their school yard holding a banner with the slogan 'ARTSAKH STRONG' to express their solidarity with Armenians fighting against Azerbaijan. The students were holding Greek and Armenian flags. [size=no report]

On 5 November 2020, residents of Liopetri rallied against the construction of a sewage pumping station near their community and demanded that it is constructed 500 meters further away. [size=no report]

Elections/referendum: On 5 November 2020, in the middle of proceedings to elect the new leader of ruling party UBP, who would also become automatically the next Prime Minister of Northern Cyprus [coded to Nicosia], both candidates withdrew from the elections before the second round without offering any reasonable explanation. Elections for the next Prime Minister were postponed for 10 months and Ersin Tatar, the former Prime Minister until he was recently elected President of Northern Cyprus, appointed the General Secretary of UBP as temporary party leader and Prime Minister, and gave him the mandate to form a government. There were widespread allegations of interference by Turkey and organizations affiliated to UBP started resigning from the party.

Security measures: On 4 November 2020, the Government of Cyprus announced a partial lockdown in the Republic of Cyprus [coded to Nicosia] with a 10-person maximum for gatherings at home or any public space among other measures, and a night curfew from 11pm starting on 5 November, due to a resurgence in the coronavirus pandemic. Additional measures were imposed on Pafos and Limassol that had a worse epidemiological profile. On 12 November, a travel ban was imposed to and from Pafos and Limassol and a stricter curfew from 8pm. The measures will be valid until 30 November.

Movement of forces: On 4 November 2020, just a few hours after the first meeting between the President of Cyprus and the new Turkish Cypriot leader, Turkey issued a Navtex for seismic survey in parts of offshore blocks 5 and 6 [coded to Coast of Pafos] until 16 February moving Barbaros and its supporting military vessels from blocks 6 and 7, undermining attempts to create space for dialogue. The Turkish Navtex reserves part of the maritime area, which has been legally demarcated between the Republic of Cyprus and Egypt with a bilateral EEZ boundary agreement in 2003.
AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; DIKO: Democratic Party; Cyprus Green Party

On 30 October 2020, members of AKEL, DIKO and the Cyprus Green Party participated in an anti-corruption rally outside a new academic institute in Pafos, while the opening ceremony was taking place inside and where the President of Cyprus was present, in the wake of the passports scandal brought to light by the Al Jazeera network. [size=no report]

On 29 October 2020, dozens of Polish women dressed in black rallied outside the embassy of Poland in Nicosia to protest against an almost-total abortion ban ruling and to express their solidarity with demonstrations in their home country. Some of the protesters were holding black umbrellas. [size=dozens]

On 29 October 2020, business owners of evening private schools for sports, social and cultural extra-curricular activities for minors, protested in Limassol against the government's latest coronavirus measures, which suspend these activities. [size=no report]

On 28 October 2020, around 1,000 demonstrators, who were organised online, rallied in Limassol against the government's coronavirus measures, against corruption, and against 5G technology. About 400 hooded demonstrators rioted with a subgroup of 100 making use of flares and fireworks, and setting trash cans on fire. They hurled rocks and other objects at police and torched a police vehicle using petrol bombs. The officers in the vehicle escaped unharmed, but 4 other officers and a firefighter were injured and transferred to hospital. Other patrol cars and private vehicles in the area were also damaged. 7 suspects were detained briefly. [size=around 1,000]

On 27 October 2020, more than 150 Muslims, who arrived from Limassol and Nicosia, rallied outside the French embassy in Nicosia to demonstrate against the government of France following the beheading of a teacher and the projection of Charlie Hebdo cartoons onto government buildings in France, and the reaction of Turkish President Erdogan against French President Macron. About 20 of the demonstrators clashed with police after they took down the embassy's French flag and destroyed it. There were 4 arrests. [size=more than 150]

On 27 October 2020, senior high school students of Dali protested at their school against the opening of part of uninhabited Varosha in Famagusta violating UN resolutions. The students shouted slogans and waved Greek and Cypriot flags. [size=no report]

On 25 October 2020, members of the Armenian community of Cyprus participated in a motorcade in Nicosia to protest against Azeri attacks at Nagorno-Karabakh. The protesters drove by the embassies of the United States, Russia, France and Israel. [size=no report]

On 24 October 2020, people participated in an anti-corruption rally in Nicosia in the wake of the passports scandal brought to light by the Al Jazeera network, demanding justice and a legal investigation on the matter. [size=no report]

On 24 October 2020, protesters against the governments coronavirus measures rallied outside the Presidential palace in Nicosia holding banners and placards with messages against the use of face masks and against vaccines. [size=no report]

On 23 October 2020, members of the Cyprus Green Party rallied in Nicosia demanding the dissolution of parliament after lawyers and officials involved in the Cyprus passport scheme were exposed as corrupt in an undercover Al Jazeera video. [size=no report]

On 22 October 2020, some 350 people marched from the Ministry of the Interior to the Presidential palace in Nicosia in the wake of the passports scandal brought to light by the Al Jazeera network, which resulted in the resignations of an AKEL lawmaker and of the President of the House of Representatives. The protesters, who were organized by 'Active Citizens', a non-partisan loose grouping of concerned citizens, placed a mock-up coffin on the perimeter wall of the presidential palace, with the words 'Integrity, Transparency and Honesty.' [size=some 350]
Health Workers (Cyprus); Government of Cyprus (2013-); PEO: Pancyprian Federation of Labour; Labour Group (Cyprus)

On 22 October 2020, tens of employees at the Famagusta coronavirus reference hospital, mostly nurses, protested outside the hospital to express their solidarity with 3 nurses about to lose their jobs. The mayor of Deryneia and a representative of PEO also participated in the protest, as well as many citizens, who joined the protest spontaneously wanting to express their gratitude to nursing staff at the hospital. [size=tens]
On 21 October 2020, members of the administrative staff in state schools protested in Nicosia, demanding permanent positions. [size=no report]

On 21 October 2020, about 150 school and university students protested in Nicosia against the opening of part of Varosha in Famagusta by Turkish Cypriot leader Ersin Tatar violating UN resolutions. The protest took place outside the Presidential palace during a trilateral summit between Nicosia, Cairo and Athens. [size=about 150]

On 20 October 2020, members of EDON protested at the Deryneia checkpoint for the liberation and unification of Cyprus and for Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots to live together in a federal Cyprus. [size=no report]

On 19 October 2020, hundreds of protesters marched to the Presidential mansion in Nicosia following new revelations after lawyers and officials involved in the Cyprus passport scheme were exposed as corrupt in an undercover Al Jazeera video. The protesters, who were holding banners - some of them reading 'Refugees welcome' - shouted slogans against corruption, against institutional and social racism, and demanded the President of the Republic of Cyprus resign. [size=hundreds]

On 17 October 2020, hundreds of motorcyclists from all major cities of the Republic of Cyprus, all members of the 'Initiative in Memory of Isaak-Solomou', rallied at the Deryneia crosspoint with the slogan 'We are all from Famagusta - We are all from Kyrenia' to protest against the opening of part of Varosha in Famagusta violating UN resolutions. The organisers refused the participation of anyone carrying partisan insignia. There was strong police and military presence on both sides, including members of the peacekeeping force in the buffer zone. On the other side of the crossing point, citizens of Northern Cyprus, both Turkish Cypriots and settlers from Turkey, including young children, rallied in a counter-protest. They were shouting 'Cyprus is and always will be Turkish' and performed with their hands the symbol of the Turkish ultra-nationalist organisation Grey Wolves. Neither side was allowed to approach the checking point. 20 members of the Water Sports Federation of the Republic of Cyprus protested in their speed boats to express their solidarity to the motorcyclists. The coast guard of Northern Cyprus was observing them from a distance. [size=hundreds]
Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); CTP: Republican Turkish Party

On 16 October 2020, a day before the 2nd round of the Presidential elections in Northern Cyprus, an election rally in Nicosia by supporters of independent candidate Mustafa Akinci turned into a march for democracy, self-determination and a bi-communal solution to the Cyprus problem. The protesters marched with the slogan 'Peace in Cyprus Cannot be Prevented'. Akinci and the leader of CTP, attended the march with their followers, as well as other political party leaders, young people and members of NGOs. [size=no report]
EDEK: Movement for Social Democracy; Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

On 15 October 2020, members of EDEK rallied at the Deryneia crosspoint to protest against the opening of part of Varosha in Famagusta by the government of Northern Cyprus in agreement with Turkey, violating UN resolutions. [size=no report]

On 14 October 2020, about 3,000 protesters rallied outside the House of Representatives in Nicosia after lawyers and officials involved in the Cyprus passport scheme were exposed as corrupt in an undercover Al Jazeera video, and they demanded the resignation of everyone involved in the scandal.[size=no report]

On 14 October 2020, students of another school in Engomi in Nicosia continued the trend of protesting during school breaks against the opening of the beachfront in Varosha in Famagusta violating UN resolutions. The students shouted 'Freedom to Famagusta' and sang the national anthem. [size=no report]

On 13 October 2020, protesters rallied outside the House of Representatives in Nicosia after lawyers and officials involved in the Cyprus passport scheme were exposed as corrupt in an undercover Al Jazeera video. [size=no report]
AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; DIKO: Democratic Party; EDEK: Movement for Social Democracy; Government of Cyprus (2013-)

On 12 October 2020, members of the Citizens' Initiative participated in a sit-in protest outside the city hall of Pafos to protest over the diminishing green urban areas and the recent cutting of 118 trees along a popular avenue in the city. City Councillors of AKEL, DIKO, EDEK and of the Movement for the Salvation of Pafos also participated in the protest. [size=no report]

On 11 October 2020, tens of Turkish Cypriots rallied in Northern Cyprus at the Deryneia crossing point holding Turkish flags as a response to the Greek Cypriot riots on the other side of the crossing point. There was strong police and military presence. [size=tens]

On 11 October 2020, members of EDON participated in an antifascist march from the Greek Embassy to the Presidential Palace in Nicosia following the conviction of Golden Dawn in Greece as a criminal organisation, and they demanded the government take more effective measures against fascist groups including ELAM, which was affiliated to Golden Dawn. [size=no report]
Yeniduzen; LGC News; Ekathimerini; The National Herald; Philenews; Detay

Elections/referendum: On 11 October 2020, Northern Cyprus held presidential elections [coded to Nicosia} - that would affect the future of Cyprus peace talks - under allegations of an unprecedented level of Turkish interference aiming to influence the election's outcome in favour of its preferred candidate and leader of the UBP party, Ersin Tatar, against independent candidate and moderate Mustafa Akinci. Tatar advocates fully aligning Turkish Cypriot policies with those of Ankara, such as pursuing a two-state deal for Cyprus, which means permanent partition of the two communities, while Akinci is an advocate for a bi-communal, bi-zonal federation to reunify the ethnically divided island. Neither garnered the required majority to win outright. On 18 October, in the second round of the elections, Tatar defeated Akinci.

On 11 October 2020, about 250 Greek Cypriot nationalists, likely ELAM according to Turkish Cypriot reports, wearing masks and hoods and dressed in black, demonstrated at the Deryneia crossing point to the North following the opening of Varosha beachfront in Famagusta violating UN resolutions. Some of the demonstrators breached the police checkpoint and moved into the buffer zone (aka the Green Line). Greek Cypriot reports also pointed to the fans of a Greek Cypriot Famagusta football club. The rioters were holding bats and sticks and they were chanting 'Cyprus is Greek'. They lit torches and hurled flares causing fires in nearby fields. They also caused damages to other properties. Police arrived an hour later and dispersed the demonstrators. In the following days, there were 9 detentions of which 6 turned into arrests. [size=about 250]

Non-violent activity: On 6 October 2020, the People's Party (HP) and its leader Kudret Ozersay, the Foreign Secretary of Northern Cyprus, withdrew from the UBP-HP coalition - breaking the government coalition - following the opening of a part of Varosha/Maras in Famagusta by Prime Minister Ersin Tatar, and presidential candidate in the 11 October presidential elections, in agreement with Turkish President Erdogan and without consulting the Council of Ministers or the Foreign Secretary. The other presidential candidates and journalists accused Turkey of interfering with elections in Northern Cyprus and of threatening press freedom. Labour groups and the Famagusta Initiative also opposed Tatar's move as a provocative action that does not reflect the political will of the Turkish Cypriot community as it violates UN resolutions and might derail the resumption of Cyprus talks.

On 6 August, the Turkish drillship Yavuz began operating south of the Karpasia (Karpaz) Peninsula. The exploratory activities in the East Mediterranean are taking place under the protection of the Turkish Armed Forces and has been causing increased tensions throughout the year.
Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); YDP: Rebirth Party; Former Government of Northern Cyprus (2015-2020)

On 2 August 2019, two days after the suspended march that set off from the district of Iskele, protesters from the Karpaz peninsula with the support of their municipal leaders and the Rebirth Party (YDP) marched in Northern Nicosia and left a black wreath in parliament to protest over the indifference of the administration of Northern Cyprus for the problems of their region with the slogan ''''If there is no Karpaz, there is no TRNC''''. [size=no report]

On 2 August, members of the Movement Against Foreclosures and the social platform 'a Roof for Everyone' rallied in front of Parliament in Nicosia, while this issue is being discussed in the House of Representatives, to protest against foreclosures with the slogan 'housing is a human right'. More than 50 police officers with 20 police cars were present. [size=no report]
YDP: Rebirth Party; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
Former Police Forces of Northern Cyprus (2015-2020)

On 31 July 2019, 100-150 protesters from the Iskele district in the Karpaz peninsula supported by the Rebirth Party (YDP) rallied at the Ziyamet-Gelincik junction [coded to Famagusta], where they started marching towards Nicosia to protest over the indifference of the administration in Northern Cyprus for the problems of their region, which remains underdeveloped. When protesters reached the village of Cayirova and tried to reach the hotels' area because of a fainting protester, they were intercepted by police. [size=100-150]
ELAM: National Peoples Front; Military Forces of Cyprus (2013-)

On 31 July, unidentified assailants riding a large motorcycle without a license plate attempted to murder an ELAM councillor of Limassol and staff member of the National Guard, who was previously investigated by police on bombing related cases. He was shot in the back once and the gun was jammed during the second shot. His life was saved, but he became paraplegic.
Movement for the Right to Housing; Cyprus Green Party; EDEK: Movement for Social Democracy; ELAM: National Peoples Front

On 29 July, protesters against foreclosures, who rallied outside parliament while the issue was being discussed in the House of Representatives demanding amendments to the law, reported that police pushed them away because they wanted to continue protesting during the scheduled visit of the Greek Prime Minister, who was visiting Cyprus. The protesters were supported by the Movement for the Right to Housing, the Cyprus Green Party, EDEK and ELAM. A disabled man was reportedly hit and a member of the Green party fainted. [size=no report]

On 25 July, for the second week in a row, the community leader of Argaka accompanied by locals obstructed international experts from placing special aluminum cages above nests to protect turtle eggs and hatchlings from foxes at Argaka beach. The environmentalists complained that police is siding with the locals who construct illegal beach bars and place sun-beds and umbrellas in protected beaches. [size=no report]
On 25 July, young Turkish-Cypriots who are members of the Nicosia Folklore Association marched in northern Nicosia to protest over the high number of deaths due to traffic accidents. [size=no report]

On 25 July, the movement Independence Road protested in front of the Prime Ministry in northern Nicosia against the financial protocol and education agreement between the administration of Northern Cyprus and the Republic of Turkey. Turkish Cypriots, who are secular, perceive this protocol as forced Islamisation and favouritism over Turkish migrant settlers. [size=no report]
Former Military Forces of Northern Cyprus (2015-2020)

Movement of forces: On 25 July 2019, the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister of Northern Cyprus accompanied by Turkish military and a team of experts entered Varosha, the ''''ghost town'''' of Famagusta, to inspect the area ahead of resettlement plans under Turkish Cypriot administration, which are against UN resolutions and continuous efforts of the legitimate citizens of Famagusta to return to their city.

On 23 July, as announced by Turkish Defence Ministry, Turkey's drillships near the coast of Pafos are being constantly monitored by the Turkish military navy with the use of Bayraktar TB-2 type drones, helicopters and airplane of the Turkish port authority, and by submarines and corvette warships at sea. This was after Turkey's Foreign Minister stated that no further energy exploration or drilling ships would be needed in the eastern Mediterranean in a conciliatory move ahead of the first meeting in six months between the Turkish and Greek Cypriot leaders in August.
Labour Group (Cyprus); PEO: Pancyprian Federation of Labour; SEK: Cyprus Workers Confederation

On 23 July, the 16 staff at a home for the elderly in Larnaca supported by their unions Pancyprian Federation of Labour (PEO) and Cyprus Workers Confederation (SEK) protested over the lack of staff and security in their facility, which previously hosted only 10 elderly people and now it accommodates another 40 unaccompanied minors due to lack of space in migrant facilities. [size=16]

On 23 July, around 50 people at the Menogeia Immigration Detention centre in Larnaca protested over 'a corrupt system' of the immigration department, claiming they are detained unjustly without being given a satisfactory reason. They also complained that they are being served the same food daily and went on hunger strike. [size=about 50]

On 19 July, the Head of Argaka municipality and local residents protested at Argaka beach, which is within the Natura 2000 Network area, against a group of international experts who were licensed by the Department for Fisheries and Marine Research to place special cages for the protection of turtle eggs on the beach. The residents of Argaka tried to prevent the cage placement and demanded to see the turtle eggs. Police was called and the protesters were removed from the beach. The Head of Argaka municipality questioned the existence of turtle eggs and claimed the programme was launched under false pretenses. [size=no report]
Kurdish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Cyprus Green Party

On 13 July, members of the Kurdistan Cultural Centre Theofilos and other supporters including members of the Green movement gathered at Larnaca court in solidarity with a Kurdish recognised refugee and resident of Cyprus on the day the court would decide after lengthy procedures whether to extradite him to Germany on 'terrorist' charges after the latter issued an international arrest warrant. The verdict was that he was being targeted for his political beliefs and he was set free. [size=no report]
On 12 July, members of the Pancyprian Federation of Labour rallied in Limassol to protest against the fourth labour accident this year that resulted in a worker's death. [size=no report]

As reported on 11 July, a Turkish Cypriot bus driver was attacked by Greek Cypriot drivers with stones and water bottles when he was collecting 25 tourists from Hungary that were staying in the north of the island. He was then chased out of the airport. The incident gained prominence when the Turkish Cypriot president brought it to the attention of the Greek Cypriot President through the UN representative and an investigation was launched through the bicommunal crime committee. The Greek Cypriot account of events differs.

Non-violent activity: On 11 July 2019, the Turkish Cypriot administration deported by boat to Turkey 51 Syrian refugees including a pregnant woman and four children, who were staying at an abandoned building in Ercan airport [coded to Nicosia], which Greek Cypriots refer to as the illegal Tymbou airport, in Northern Cyprus.

On 10 July, members of the Movement Against Foreclosures prevented the foreclosure of three homes in Larnaca by creating a human chain around the residences and preventing with their presence bidders to enter the properties. [size=no report]
Greek Reporter; Ekathimerini; Philenews; The National Herald

On 8 July, Yavuz, a second drillship for exploration of gas and oil positioned itself 20km south of the coast of Cape Apostolos Andreas in Karpasia (Karpaz) peninsula in the territorial waters of Cyprus. It is accompanied by two supporting ships and a warship. Yavuz is also supported by TB2 army drones. This triggered a strong response from the internationally recognised Republic of Cyprus supported by the newly elected Greek government, the US, Russia and Egypt. The EU issued a series of warnings to Turkey and by the end of the week all 28 member states agreed on a draft of sanctions against Turkey, which Cyprus considers to be soft.
AP; Philenews; Ekathimerini; Cyprus News Agency

Non-violent activity: On 5 July 2019, a Turkish military submarine reported to be protecting the two Turkish drillships and the research ship Barbaros anchored at Kyrenia in Northern Cyprus. The Cyprus Defence Minister said this is an unrelated event and there is no need for alarm. In the meantime, Turkey announced that the second drillship Yavuz will be deployed in the Karpaz peninsula in Northern Cyprus the following week despite a statement by the Cyprus Defence Minister that the same procedure as with Fatih will be followed and international arrest warrants will be issued against companies cooperating with the state-owned Turkish petroleum company.
AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; DISY: Democratic Rally

On 5 July, residents of Mammari and the surrounding area in the outskirts of Nicosia protested against the 'unbearable smell' of livestock and chicken farms in close proximity to their homes. Representatives of political parties AKEL and DISY were present at the protest. [size=no report]
To Vima; The National Herald; Philenews; Ekathimerini; Cyprus News Agency

On 3 July, Turkey transported 42 German Leopard-2A4 tanks along with their ammunition from Turkey's First Army in the Evros region to Kythrea in Northern Cyprus. This violates the ban by Germany and the US forbidding the transfer to Cyprus of weapons systems that they have constructed. The next day the Turkish President and the Turkish FM made statements threatening the use of force. The President of Cyprus called for Turkey to respect international law and for a sense of conciliation to prevail so that once tensions have come to an end, a resumption of negotiations will be possible.

Non-violent activity: On 2 July 2019, the prime minister of Turkish-occupied Northern Cyprus announced that considering the current situation in the Eastern Mediterranean, Varosha, the southern quarter of Famagusta, will not be part of the Confidence Building Measures any more and it will be opened for settlement, despite the fact that it is protected by a 1984 UN Security Council resolution according to which the empty town can only be resettled by its original mostly Greek Cypriot inhabitants. The announcement signals further deterioration of Cyprus-Turkish relations in the context of an escalating drilling dispute off the Cyprus coast.
Cyprus Green Party; AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Citizens Alliance; DISY: Democratic Rally; Journalists (Cyprus); Government of Cyprus (2013-); Women (Cyprus)

On 2 July, hundreds of men and women rallied outside police headquarters in Nicosia holding black banners with the slogan 'Not One Less' to protest against domestic violence and the recent killings of women. They placed 39 red shoes on the pavement, a symbolic number, one for every woman killed by their husbands or ex-husbands since 2000, as well as the number of calls the helpline receives daily. Members of the Green Party, AKEL, DISY, Citizens Alliance, the Union of Cyprus' Journalists and the government council Voice also participated. [size=hundreds]
AP; Haravgi; Ekathimerini; To Vima; Philenews

On 1 July, early in the morning a stray S-200 Russian-made Syrian missile struck the mountain village of Vouno (Tashkent) in Northern Cyprus starting a fire. The accidental incident occurred during military operations in the Middle East between Israel and Syria more than 300km away. The explosion was thought to have occurred before impact because there were no craters, and debris was found at several different points. Police cordoned off the main debris field and some homes were evacuated. No injuries were reported and there were no toxic emissions.

On 1 July, dialysis patients supported by their local MPs protested outside Pafos hospital against serious problems facing the renal unit, which they claim is operating against EU health standards. The protesters demanded the government overcomes bureaucratic delays and speeds up the construction of the new unit. [size=no report]

On 29 June, tension in the Eastern Mediterranean and the Aegean continued with Turkey sending a second drillship to Cyprus for the exploration of oil and gas. The drillship Yavuz set off for the Karpaz peninsula in Northern Cyprus. Cyprus issued a Navtex for military exercises in the area using real fire as a response to this move and to a similar Navtex by Turkey. In the meantime, Turkey has also been violating Greek and Cyprus airspace more often than usual and the USA Senate voted overwhelmingly in favour of the East Med Act reforming their geopolitical strategy in the area including lifting the arms sales embargo on Cyprus and monitoring Turkish violations in Cyprus' exclusive economic zone.

On 28 June, after the recent incidents regarding Varosha hundreds of people rallied outside the presidential palace in Nicosia waving flags with the word 'peace' in both Greek and Turkish to protest for the need for Famagusta to return to the forefront of discussions of the UN Security Council and for the return to the negotiating table and reunification of the island. Members of ultranationalist ELAM attempted to replace the protesters' banner with one of their own creating a disruption but they were pushed away. [size=hundreds]
Philenews; Greek Reporter; Cyprus Mail; Ekathimerini

Non-violent activity: On 18 June 2019, amid tension in the Eastern Mediterranean and on the same day as the EU General Affairs Council meeting deciding to draw up measures against Turkey for its drilling activities, the administration in the Turkish-occupied northern part of Cyprus decided to open Varosha, the southern quarter of Famagusta, for settlement, although it is protected by a 1984 UN Security Council resolution, stating that the empty town can only be resettled by its original inhabitants. On 21 June the administration of Northern Cyprus said it never spoke of opening Varosha, only of cataloguing the condition of properties.
Greek Reporter; AP; Ekathimerini; Detay; Cyprus News Agency; Philenews

On 14 June, the FM of Turkey confirmed the Turkish drilling vessel Fatih had started drilling for oil and gas 'right in the west of Cyprus' and that Turkey would be sending a second vessel. The previous day Cypriot officials had confirmed that Cyprus had issued arrest warrants against companies, company executives and crew who are involved in the operations of the Fatih. International crew withdrew. Ankara said Nicosia 'crossed a line' and they would give 'the necessary response', if Fatih employees are arrested.

On 5 June, shop owners of a central street in Nicosia about to be pedestrianised protested against this by rallying at the street, although 3,000 citizens signed a petition supporting the pedestrianisation plans. The city council voted for the street to remain pedestrian. [size=no report]

On 5 June 2019, about 250 members of the Bondholders' Association rallied at the roundabout outside of the Presidential Palace in Nicosia blocking traffic to demonstrate against the government and demand compensation. There was unrest when a police officer suggested they move on from the road for their safety. [size=about 250]
Movement for the Right to Housing

On 5 June, members of the Movement for the Right to Housing rallied in Limassol unfurling a large banner at the Germasogeia roundabout with the slogan 'Limassol, the city of homeless people' to protest for the rights of hundreds of citizens that cannot afford housing. The Movement protested against the government that portrays Limassol as an affluent city ignoring the social exclusion of a large part of the population and claims that they reneged on their promise for the establishment of a Homeless Centre. [size=no report]
Kurdish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Government of Cyprus (2013-)

On 3 June, a group of Kurdish people, also supported by members of political parties in Cyprus, rallied in front of the Larnaca district court holding flags of Cyprus, Kurdistan and of Kurdish leader Abdullah Ocalan, to protest against the arrest of a recognised Kurdish political refugee and resident of Cyprus after a Hamburg court issued an arrest warrant on alleged terrorism-related charges. He was initially arrested in April sparking protests, released briefly and arrested again on an international arrest warrant. [size=no report]

On 1 June, residents of Kato Moni protested against the illegal expansion of a nearby abattoir, which they believe is responsible for the increased number of cancer cases in their village. [size=no report]
Former Military Forces of Northern Cyprus (2015-2020)

Movement of forces: On 31 May 2019, military forces of Northern Cyprus entered the buffer zone at the Greek Cypriot village of Deneia and blocked the way with two military vehicles, while accompanying settlers in North Cyprus from Turkey, who came in with agricultural machines and harvested the wheat crops of Greek Cypriots. United Nations Forces arrived at the area but could not prevent the harvesting. Similar tension occurred on 16 November 2018.

On 30 May, residents of Deutera and priests of a nearby Monastery protested against the building of a petrol station above the monastery cave that is of historical significance. The protesters holding banners and shouting slogans blocked traffic in front of the land where the petrol station is to be built by resting a coffin in the middle of the road. [size=no report]
AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; DIKO: Democratic Party; ELAM: National Peoples Front

On 29 May, members of the Movement Against Foreclosures formed a human block in front of a property in Larnaca belonging to three families preventing prospective buyers from entering to protest against a law they believe is facilitating aggressive foreclosures. At the same time, members of parliament and members of political parties AKEL, DIKO, ELAM and other citizens rallied in protest over the same issue outside the offices of the foreclosures organisation in central Larnaca. [size=30]

On 19 May, three Nigerian nationals were arrested in Nicosia for the killing in the early hours of the morning of an asylum seeker from Cameroon when he went to a night club frequented by migrants. He was stabbed with a broken wine bottle and he bled to death. Contrary to the initial impression that it was a drug related crime, it was revealed that the Nigerians did not want other nationalities in what they perceived as their own area. One of the three confessed.

As reported on 17 May, a group of gay people were targeted outside a bakery because of their sexual orientation. The unidentified assailants hurled insults at them and punched them. The victims reported that police was unhelpful. The event was highlighted on the occasion of the International Day Against Homophobia, Transphobia and Biphobia. [size=no report]

On 16 May, tens of Pafos citizens rallied in front of the central branch of the Bank of Cyprus to protest against foreclosures and unfair bank charges accusing also the state and Parliament of doing the banks' bidding. The demonstrators shouted slogans and threw eggs at the entrance of the Pafos branch. [size=tens]

On 13 May, around 100 public service contract workers marched from the finance ministry to the presidential palace in Nicosia as part of their 48 hour strike to protest for getting the same treatment as their colleagues with permanent posts according to EU law. Two more days of action followed with a march preceded by motorcycles and protesters using drums and bullhorns, and holding placards and banners and hundreds of protesters rallying in front of the presidential palace. [size=100]
On 12 May, residents of Dali, which is surrounded by five industrial areas, protested against air pollution in their area because of the unbearable smells. [size=no report]

On 12 May, women part of the Mothers Rise Up campaign in Cyprus marched from the House of Representatives to the Presidential Palace to protest against climate change. Similar events inspired by the students' movement were held internationally. [size=no report]

On 9 May, scouts, elementary school students and their marching band, organised by the Traffic Accident Prevention Association marched in Iskele (Trikomo) in North Cyprus [coded to Famagusta] with the slogan 'Notice Me in Traffic' to protest against drink driving and other traffic violations. [size=no report]

On 8 May, employees of Citizen Service Centres supported by trade union Isotita (Equality) in combination with a country-wide strike rallied in front of the finance and trade ministries in Nicosia, while those in other towns gathered outside the citizen service centres, to protest for the government to comply with the EU directive on fixed-term employment. This calls for equal treatment of contract staff with the comparable permanent staff that perform the same or similar duties. [size=no report]

On 7 May, scouts, elementary school students and their marching band, organised by the Traffic Accident Prevention Association marched for the first time in Kyrenia with the slogan 'Notice Me in Traffic'. [size=no report]

On 5 May, a memorial and solidarity march with the migrant communities of Cyprus was organised in Limassol by the collective Spirithkia to protest against 'the racist face of Cyprus society' in the aftermath of a series of killings of female migrant workers by a captain of the National Guard. In the march participated members of the Filipino community of Cyprus and other migrants. [size=no report]

On 3 May, the government of Turkey announced that the Turkish drill Fatih will start exploratory drilling for oil and gas 40 nautical miles off the coast of Pegeia, Pafos, in the Exclusive Economic Zone of Cyprus setting in motion a chain of diplomatic reactions. All 28 EU foreign ministers confirmed their support for Cyprus calling Turkey to refrain from illegal action. In addition to EU member states, USA, Russia, China and Egypt also expressed their support. Ten days later Ankara announced they will be sending the drill ship Yavuz to join the Fatih off the coast of Cyprus. No actual drilling has occurred yet.
AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Women (Cyprus)

On 3 May, a protest event titled 'Protest for the ignored women' took place in front of the presidential palace in Nicosia for the victims of the captain of the Cyprus National Guard. Political party AKEL referred to institutional racism and sexism. [size=no report]

On 3 May, Youth for Climate Cyprus organised a silent protest in front of Parliament with the slogan 'Do you drink water? Do you breathe air? Then this is of immediate concern to you'. The young protesters had covered their mouths with ribbons reading 'Help Me'. Other citizens also protested against climate change in front of the Ministry of Agriculture and against the President of the Parliament, who did not allow them to protest in front of the Parliament building. [size=no report]
Filipino Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Labour Group (Cyprus); PEO: Pancyprian Federation of Labour; Women (Cyprus)

On 1 May, after the recent killings of Filipino women by a captain of the Cyprus National Guard, women from the Philippines working in Cyprus participated en masse at the Labour Day march in Limassol organised by the Pancyprian Federation of Labour (PEO). [size=no report]
Filipino Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Journalists (Cyprus); Government of Cyprus (2013-); Women (International)

On 26 April, hundreds to 1,000 people of all ages and nationalities including politicians, artists, journalists, members of Filipino organisations, rallied in front of the presidential palace in Nicosia for a protest vigil to mourn 5 women and 2 girls who according to the police were killed by a captain of the National Guard that confessed. The protesters questioned the way police handled the disappearance of migrant women workers, mostly Filipinos, and decried 'sexist, misogynist and racist' attitudes. A group of Filipino women held prayers. [size=hundreds-1,000]
Kurdish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Cyprus Green Party; AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; EDEK: Movement for Social Democracy

On 24 April, members of the Kurdistan Cultural Centre Theophilos supported by the Cyprus Green Party, AKEL and EDEK, protested once more against the arrest of a recognised Kurdish political refugee and resident of Cyprus after Germany issued a European arrest warrant on alleged terrorism-related charges. The protesters gathered in front of the Larnaca district court holding Cyprus flags, a photograph of Kurdish leader Abdullah Ocalan and banners reading among other slogans 'Europe fulfil your democratic values'. [size=no report]
Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Labour Group (Cyprus); ELAM: National Peoples Front; Government of Cyprus (2013-)

On 23 April 2019, 70 Greek Cypriots - originally from the north of Cyprus and former managers of a Larnaca estate that originally belonged to Turkish Cypriots - rallied in front of the estate holding banners and briefly raising a Turkish flag as a protest against the Ministry of Interior and the Guardian of Turkish Cypriot property, which ruled that they were trespassing and using the estate illegally. A city councillor of Larnaca and members of ELAM supported the rally. [size=70]

Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Cyprus Green Party; YKP: New Cyprus Party; BKP: United Cyprus Party; KSP: Cyprus Socialist Party; PEO: Pancyprian Federation of Labour; Teachers (Cyprus); EDON: United Democratic Youth Organisation; POGO: Womens Movement; Pancyprian Peace Council

On 22 April, Greek and Turkish Cypriots protested in Nicosia against plans for a nuclear plant in Akkuyu, Turkey, opposite Kyrenia. Members of AKEL, Cyprus Green Party, YKP, BKP, KSP, PEO, the Association of Cyprus Turkish Teachers, EDON, Women's Movement POGO and members of the Pancyprian Peace Council held each other forming a human chain and read a common statement against nuclear power both in Greek and in Turkish. Many were wearing yellow vests. [size=no report]

On 16 April, asylum seekers protested in Nicosia for more rights and opportunities regarding their employment status. They marched from the Ministry of Labour to the European Union House and then rallied in front of the Parliament of Cyprus. [size=no report]

On 15 April, two camps of protesters holding banners and placards rallied in front of the Municipal Hall of Pafos during the city council's meeting regarding the erection of a church cathedral in the Municipal Gardens. Unlike supporters of the Metropolitan Church, citizens' groups ask that the gardens remain a green space. The city council had previously decided against this motion on 22 March and 4 April but after lobbying by church groups and city councillors the decision was overturned. [size=no report]
Government of Cyprus (2013-); Cyprus Green Party; Orthodox Christian Group (Cyprus)

On 14 April, the Initiative Group of Pyrga-Kornos and the Friends of the Stavrovouni Monastery rallied in front of the Presidential Palace holding banners and shouting slogans to protest against the building of a new factory for the production and recycling of asphalt in their area near a protected NATURA 2000 forest. They were joined by their MPs, MEPs, municipal authorities, mayors, representatives of political parties and green organisations. There were allegations that President Anastasiades attempted to 'buy out' the environmental activists. [size=no report]

On 12 April, members of the Initiative for Saving the Natural Coastline and members of the movement Save Akamas/Save Cyprus protested by blocking symbolically the entrance of the Department for the Environment in Nicosia. The protest took place a day after a decision was announced allowing building on the coastline at a distance shorter than 100 meters from the sea in the natural habitat of the Mediterranean seal Monachus Monachus, which is an endangered species. [size=no report]

On 9 April, residents of Orounta in the district of Nicosia managed to break through a police cordon and prevent employees of a mobile phone company to install a mobile phone mast in their village. [size=no report]

On 7 April, four asylum seekers from Cameroon, Nigeria, Egypt and Turkey hosted at the Menogeia reception centre demonstrated demanding to be released. The demonstrators kicked plastic bins and threw garbage on the walls, they overturned garbage bins in the hallway and in the restaurant, and one of them broke a wall frame and started shouting in the corridor. The reception centre manager with the help of the Head of the Immigration Office and Larnaca police negotiators managed to calm them down. [size=4]

On 7 April, 6-7 activists protested against animal torture in Nicosia. They protested at a main city street wearing animal masks and lay on sheets full of 'blood' while animal cries could be heard through speakers. [size=6-7]

On 4 April, Limassol public transport bus drivers (EMEL) and their unions PEO and SEK protested all day outside the transport and labour ministries over non-payment of wages and benefits. [size=no report]

On 3 April, members of the Turkish Cypriot Secondary Education Teachers' Union (KTOEOS) participated at a sit-in protest in front of the Public Service Commission in Nicosia to draw attention to the lack of teacher job vacancies in Northern Cyprus. [size=no report]
Kurdish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Cyprus Green Party

On 2 April, in Larnaca, members of the Kurdistan Cultural Centre Theophilos supported by the Green Party MP , protested against the arrest of a recognised Kurdish political refugee and resident of Cyprus after Germany issued a European arrest warrant on alleged terrorism-related charges. [size=no report]

On 2 April, the ultra-nationalist political party National People's Front (ELAM) reported that their offices in Nicosia were attacked by an unidentified group of people , who wrote slogans on the walls and caused material damages. [size=no report]

On 27 March, 2,000-4,000 people [size=2,000-4,000] in Nicosia marched under the sound of music with five tractors leading the way to the presidential palace to protest the closure of the Cooperative Bank of Cyprus. The march was organised by farmers' unions, teachers' unions and the Cyprus Police Association. The protest was also supported by the Union of Cyprus Pensioners (EKYSY), the student union (PSEM), taxi drivers, and political parties AKEL, DIKO, EDEK, Citizens Alliance and the Cyprus Green Party.
Property destruction: On 25 March 2019, on Greek Independence Day, unidentified perpetrators set fire to an abandoned Turkish Cypriot house in the village of Kofinou.
